revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=January 2015}}
[[File:Santa maria del naranco-001.jpg|thumb|200px|right|The royal palace, later church, of [[Santa María del Naranco]], an example of [[Asturian architecture]] of the ''Ramirense'' period.]] [[File:PM 33256 P Lourosa.jpg|thumb|200px|The interior of the Church of São Pedro da Lourosa (Lourosa, [[Portugal]]).]] [[File:Kopčany kostol - sever.JPG|thumb|200px|right|[[Church of St. Margaret of Antioch, Kopčany]] ([[Kopčany]], [[Slovakia]], 9th-10th century).]] '''Pre-Romanesque art and architecture''' is the period in European art from either the emergence of the [[Merovingian dynasty|Merovingian kingdom]] in about AD 500 or from the [[Carolingian Renaissance]] in the late 8th century, to the beginning of the 11th century [[Romanesque art|Romanesque]] period. The term is generally used in English only for [[architecture]] and [[monumental sculpture]], but here all the arts of the period are briefly described.
The primary theme during this period is the introduction and absorption of [[Classical art|classical]] Mediterranean and [[Early Christian art|Early Christian]] forms with Germanic ones, which fostered innovative new forms. This in turn led to the rise of Romanesque art in the 11th century. In the outline of [[Medieval art]] it was preceded by what is commonly called the [[Migration Period art]] of the "barbarian" peoples: [[Insular art|Hiberno-Saxon]] in the British Isles and predominantly [[Merovingian art and architecture|Merovingian]] on the Continent.
In most of western Europe, the [[Roman architecture|Roman]] architectural tradition survived the collapse of the empire. The Merovingians ([[Franks]]) continued to build large stone buildings like [[monastery]] [[church architecture|churches]] and palaces.
The unification of the Frankish kingdom under [[Clovis I]] (465–511) and his successors, corresponded with the need for the building of churches, and especially monastery churches, as these were now the power-houses of the Merovingian church. Two hundred monasteries existed south of the [[Loire]] when [[St Columbanus]], an Irish missionary, arrived in Europe in 585. Only 100 years later, by the end of the 7th century, over 400 flourished in the Merovingian kingdom alone.<ref>http://www.all-art.org/history128-2.html</ref> The building plans often continued the Roman basilica tradition.
Many Merovingian plans have been reconstructed from archaeology. The description in [[Bishop]] [[Gregory of Tours]]' ''History of the Franks'' of the basilica of Saint-Martin, built at [[Tours]] by [[Saint Perpetuus]] (bishop 460–490) at the beginning of the period and at the time on the edge of Frankish territory, gives cause to regret the disappearance of this building, one of the most beautiful Merovingian churches, which he says had 120 marble columns, towers at the East end, and several mosaics: "Saint-Martin displayed the vertical emphasis, and the combination of block-units forming a complex internal space and the correspondingly rich external silhouette, which were to be the hallmarks of the Romanesque".<ref>V.I. Atroshenko and Judith Collins, ''The Origins of the Romanesque'' (Lund Humphries, London) 1985, p. 48. {{ISBN|0-85331-487-X}}</ref>
The Merovingian dynasty were replaced by the [[Carolingian dynasty]] in AD 752, which led to [[Carolingian architecture]] from 780 to 900, and [[Ottonian architecture]] in the [[Holy Roman Empire]] from the mid-10th century until the mid-11th century. These successive Frankish dynasties were large contributors to [[Romanesque architecture]]. [[File:Baptistere Saint Sauveur by Malost.JPG|thumb|right|150px|Baptistery of [[Aix Cathedral]], AD 500, built by the [[Merovingians]]]]
==Examples of Frankish buildings== [[Merovingians|Merovingian]], [[Carolingian architecture|Carolingian]] and [[Ottonian architecture|Ottonian]] [[File:Digitale Rekonstruktion - Geometrische Ausmalung, Innenansicht.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Digital reconstruction of Ingelheim Palace, 800.]] [[File:St Michaels Church Hildesheim.jpg|thumb|200px|[[St. Michael's Church, Hildesheim]], 1031.]] [[File:Palais charlemagne.svg|thumb|right|200px|Reconstruction of [[Charlemagne]]'s palace in Aachen, 800.]]
* [[Baptistère de Riez]] built in the 4th, 5th and 7th centuries * [[Fréjus Cathedral]] circa AD 450 * [[Crypt of Saint-Laurent]] Grenoble circa 500 * [[Aix Cathedral]] circa 500, baptistery built by the [[Merovingians]] * [[Baptistère Saint-Jean]] 507 * [[Baptistère de Venasque]] circa 500 * [[Abbey of Saint-Germain-des-Prés]] circa 540 * [[Radegonde de Poitiers]] Tomb of St. Radegunda 587 * [[Jouarre Abbey]] 630, Merovingian crypt * [[Kloster Reichenau]] 724 * [[Benedictine Convent of Saint John]], Müstair 780 * [[Granusturm]] 788, 20 meter tall tower in Aarchen * [[Lorsch Abbey]], gateway, (c. 800) * [[Palatine Chapel in Aachen]] (Aix-la-Chapelle) (792–805) * [[Imperial Palace, Ingelheim]] 800 * Oratory of Bishop [[Theodulf of Orleans]] in [[Germigny-des-Prés]] 806 * [[Ursmar|St. Ursmar]]'s Collegiate church, in [[Lobbes]], [[Belgium]] (819–823) * [[St. Michael, Fulda]], rotunda and crypt (822) * [[Michelstadt#Einhard.E2.80.99s Basilica in the outlying centre of Steinbach|Einhard's Basilica]], Steinbach (827) * [[Saint Justinus' church, Frankfurt-Höchst]] (830) * [[Schloss Broich]] 883–884, Carolingian fortress * Broich Castle, Muelheim on the Ruhr (884) * [[Abbey of Corvey]] (885) * St. George, Oberzell in [[Reichenau Island]] (888) * [[St. Georg (Reichenau-Oberzell)]] 900 * [[St. Johannis (Mainz)]] 910 * [[Church of St Philibert, Tournus]] 950 * [[St. Cyriakus, Gernrode]] 969
[[Ottonian architecture|Ottonian]] and [[Holy Roman Empire]] * [[Mainz Cathedral]] begun 991 and 994 and retains some structure of this period. * [[St. Michael's Church, Hildesheim|St. Michael's Church]] Hildesheim, 1031
==Imperial styles==
===Carolingian art=== [[File:Ebbo Gospels St Mark.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Saint Mark, from the so-called [[Ebbo Gospels]], a piece of Carolingian illustration.]] {{main|Carolingian art|Carolingian architecture}}
Carolingian art is the roughly 120-year period from about 780 to 900, during [[Charlemagne]]'s and his immediate heirs' rule, popularly known as the [[Carolingian Renaissance]]. Although brief, it was very influential; northern European kings promoted classical Mediterranean Roman art forms for the first time, while also creating innovative new forms such as naturalistic figure line drawings that would have lasting influence. Carolingian churches generally are [[basilica]]n, like the [[Early Christian art and architecture|Early Christian]] churches of Rome, and commonly incorporated [[westwork]]s, which is arguably the precedent for the western facades of later medieval cathedrals. An original [[westwork]] survives today at the [[Abbey of Corvey]], built in 885. After a rather chaotic interval following the Carolingian period, the new [[Ottonian dynasty]] revived Imperial art from about 950, building on and further developing Carolingian style in [[Ottonian art]].
===Ottonian art=== {{main|Ottonian art|Ottonian architecture}} [[Germanic peoples|Germanic]] pre-Romanesque art during the 120-year period from 936 to 1056 is commonly called Ottonian art after the three [[Ottonian dynasty|Saxon]] emperors named Otto ([[Otto the Great|Otto I]], [[Otto II]], and [[Otto III]]) who ruled the [[Holy Roman Empire]] from 936 to 1001.
After the decline of the Carolingian Empire, the Holy Roman Empire was re-established under the Saxon (Ottonian) dynasty. From this emerged a renewed faith in the idea of Empire and a reformed Church, creating a period of heightened cultural and artistic fervour. It was in this atmosphere that masterpieces were created that fused the traditions from which Ottonian artists derived their inspiration: models of Late Antique, Carolingian, and Byzantine origin.
Much Ottonian art reflected the dynasty's desire to establish visually a link to the Christian rulers of Late Antiquity, such as [[Constantine I (emperor)|Constantine]], Theoderich, and [[Justinian]] as well as to their Carolingian predecessors, particularly [[Charlemagne]].
Ottonian monasteries produced some of the most magnificent medieval illuminated manuscripts. They were a major art form of the time, and monasteries received direct sponsorship from emperors and bishops, having the best in equipment and talent available.
==Regional styles==
===Croatia=== {{Main|Croatian Pre-Romanesque art and architecture}} [[File:Zadar2.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Pre-Romanesque Church of [[Donatus of Zadar|St Donatus]] in [[Zadar]], from the 9th century.]]
In the 7th century the [[Croats]], with other [[Slavs]] and [[Pannonian Avars|Avars]], came from Northern Europe to the region where they live today.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rastko.org.rs/arheologija/vsedov-slavs_2.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111211445/http://www.rastko.org.rs/arheologija/vsedov-slavs_2.html |archivedate=2013-11-11 |df= }}</ref> The first Croatian churches were built as royal sanctuaries, and the influence of Roman art was strongest in Dalmatia where urbanization was thickest. Gradually that influence was neglected and certain simplifications and alterations of inherited forms, and even creation of original buildings, appeared.
All of them (a dozen large ones and hundreds of small ones) were built with roughly cut stone bounded with a thick layer of malter on the outside. Large churches are longitudinal with one or three [[naves]] like [[Church of Holy Salvation, Cetina|Church of Holy Salvation]] ({{lang-hr|Crkva Sv. Spasa}}) at the spring of the river [[Cetina]], built in the 9th century, along with the [[Church of Saint Cross]] in [[Nin, Croatia|Nin]]. The largest and most complicated central based church from the 9th century is dedicated to [[Donatus of Zadar|Saint Donatus]] in [[Zadar]].
[[Altar]] rails and windows of those churches were highly decorated with transparent shallow string-like [[Ornament (architecture)|ornament]] that is called ''[[pleter]]'' (meaning to weed) because the strings were threaded and rethreaded through itself. Motifs of those reliefs were taken from Roman art; sometimes figures from the Bible appeared alongside this decoration, like ''relief in Holy Nedjeljica'' in Zadar, and then they were subdued by their pattern. This also happened to engravings in early Croatian script – [[Glagolitic]]. Soon, the Glagolitic writings were replaced with [[Latin]] on altar rails and [[architrave]]s of old-Croatian churches.
From the ''Crown Church of [[King Zvonimir]]'' (so called ''Hollow Church'' in [[Solin, Croatia|Solin]]) comes the altar board with ''figure of Croatian King'' on the throne with [[Carolingian]] crown, servant by his side and subject bowed to the king.
By joining the [[Hungary|Hungarian]] crown in the twelfth century, Croatia lost its full independence, but it did not lose its ties with the south and the west, and instead this ensured the beginning of a new era of [[Central Europe]]an cultural influence.
===England=== {{main|Anglo-Saxon art|Anglo-Saxon architecture}} [[File:Meister des Benedictionale des Heiligen Aethelwold 001.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The [[Benedictional of St. Æthelwold|Benedictional of Saint Aethelwold]], an [[List of illuminated Anglo-Saxon manuscripts|Anglo-Saxon illuminated manuscript]].]]
Anglo-Saxon art covers the period from the time of [[King Alfred]] (885), with the revival of English culture after the end of the Viking raids, to the early 12th century, when [[Romanesque art]] became the new movement. Prior to King Alfred there had been the [[Hiberno-Saxon]] culture, producing in [[Insular art]] the fusion of Anglo-Saxon and Celtic techniques and motifs, which had largely ceased in Ireland and Northern England with the [[Viking]] invasions. Anglo-Saxon art is mainly known today through [[illuminated manuscripts]] and metalwork.
===France=== After the demise of the Carolingian Empire, France split into a number of feuding provinces, so that lacking any organized Imperial patronage, French art of the 10th and 11th centuries became localised around the large monasteries, and lacked the sophistication of a court-directed style.
Multiple regional styles developed based on the chance availability of Carolingian manuscripts (as models to draw from), and the availability of itinerant artists. The monastery of [[Saint Bertin]] became an important centre under its abbot [[Odbert]] (986–1007) who created a new style based on Anglo-Saxon and Carolingian forms. The nearby abbey of [[Abbey of St. Vaast|Saint Vaast]] created a number of works. In southwestern France at the [[Abbey of Saint Martial, Limoges|monastery of Saint Martial]] in [[Limoges]] a number of manuscripts were produced around year 1000, as were produced in [[Albi]], [[Figeac]] and [[Saint-Sever-de-Rustan]] in [[Gascony]]. In Paris there developed a style at the abbey of [[Saint Germain-des-Prés]]. In [[Normandy]] a new style developed from 975 onward.
===Spain and Portugal=== {{main|Spanish Pre-Romanesque art and architecture}} [[File:Capela de S. Frutuoso.JPG|thumb|right|[[Saint Frutuoso Chapel]] in [[Braga]], Portugal.]] The first form of Pre-Romanesque in [[Spain]] and [[Portugal]] was the [[Visigothic art]], that brought the horse-shoe arches to the latter [[Moorish architecture]] and developed jewellery.
After the Moorish occupation, Pre-Romanesque art was first reduced to the [[Kingdom of Asturias]], the only Christian realm in the area at the time which reached high levels of artistic depuration. (See ''[[Asturian art]]''). The Christians who lived in Moorish territory, the [[Mozarab]]s, created their own architectural and illumination style, [[Mozarabic art]].
The best preserved Visigothic monument in [[Portugal]] is the [[Saint Frutuoso Chapel]] in [[Braga]].
===Italy=== {{see also|Lombard Romanesque}} Southern Italy benefited from the presence and cross fertilization of the Byzantines, the Arabs, and the Normans, while the north was mostly controlled first by the Carolingians. The [[Italo-Norman|Normans]] in Sicily chose to commission Byzantine workshops to decorate their churches such as [[Monreale]] and [[Cefalù Cathedral]]s where full iconographic programmes of [[mosaic]]s have survived. Important frescos and illuminated manuscripts were produced.
==See also== {{Commons category|Pre-Romanesque architecture}} {{Wikipedia books|Romanesque Art and Architecture}} * [[Asturian architecture]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * Joachim E. Gaehde (1989). "Pre-Romanesque Art". ''[[Dictionary of the Middle Ages]]''. {{ISBN|0-684-18276-9}} * Jacques Fontaine (1995) ''L'art pré-roman hispanique'', Nuit des temps, [[Editions zodiaque]] {{ISBN|2-7369-0215-7}}
==External links== * [http://www.circulo-romanico.com El Portal del Arte Románico Visigothic, Mozarabe and Romanesque art in Spain.]
{{Archhistory}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pre-Romanesque Art And Architecture}} [[Category:Pre-Romanesque architecture in Spain| ]] [[Category:Medieval architecture]] [[Category:Medieval art]] [[Category:Architectural history]] [[Category:Romanesque architecture|·]] [[Category:Western art]]

revision.text:
A '''running gag''', or '''running joke''', is a [[literary device]] that takes the form of an amusing [[joke]] or a [[comedy|comical]] reference and appears repeatedly throughout a work of [[literature]] or other form of [[storytelling]]. Though they are similar, [[catchphrase]]s are not considered running gags.<ref name="byron" /><ref name="beaver" />
Running gags can begin with an instance of [[unintentional humor]] that is repeated in variations as the joke grows familiar and [[audience]]s anticipate reappearances of the gag. The humor in a running gag may derive entirely from how often it is repeated, however the underlying statement or situation will always require some form of [https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/jocularity jocularity]. Therefore, a statement which is merely trivial in nature will not turn into a running gag simply by being repeated over and over again. A running gag may also derive its humor from the (in)appropriateness of the situation in which the gag occurs, or setting up the audience to expect another occurrence of the joke and then substituting something else (''bait and switch''). Running gags are found mostly in [[Situation comedy|television shows]],<ref name="morganrussell" /> but also appear in other places, such as [[video game]]s, [[film]]s, [[book]]s, and [[comic strip]]s.
A running gag can be verbal or visual and may "convey social values by echoing belligerent speakers with a barrage of caricatured threats."<ref name="Brunvand719">{{cite book|last=Brunvand|first=Jan Harold|authorlink=Jan Harold Brunvand|title=American Folklore : An Encyclopedia Garland Reference Library of the Humanities ; Vol. 1551|publisher=New York Garland, 1998 |isbn=978-0-8153-3350-0 |page= 719; 812}}</ref> For example, a character may present others with a proposition that is so ridiculous or outrageous it is likely to be self-mocking to the point where the original request has little or no chance of actually being carried out and results in a humorous effect.<ref name="Brunvand719"/> Occasionally, the characters themselves may be aware of the running gag and make humorous mention of it.
==See also== *[[Callback (comedy)]] *[[Catchphrase]] *[[Gimmick]] *[[In-joke]] *[[Recurring character]] *[[Trademark look]]
==References== {{reflist|refs=
<ref name="morganrussell">"... the running gag and the catchphrase, both important staples in most situation comedies …" {{cite book |author =Neale and Krutnik |title=Popular film and television comedy }}, quoted in {{cite book |last=Morgan-Russell |first=Simon |title=Jimmy Perry and David Croft |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3W97f5u9ZZEC&pg=PA2&dq=%2B%22situation+comedy%22+%2B%22running+gag%22#v=onepage |year=2004 |publisher=Manchester University Press |isbn=0-7190-6556-9 |page=2}}</ref>
<ref name="byron">"The running gag, a staple of broad comedy, depends on the watcher's reference to the passage of time".{{cite book |last=Byron |first=Mark S |title=Samuel Beckett's Endgame |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ARC8ZqHWJWQC&pg=PA82&dq=%22running+gag%22#v=onepage |isbn=978-90-420-2288-1 |year=2007 |publisher=Editions Rodopi B.V |page=82}}</ref>
<ref name="beaver">"The running gag has long been recognised as a standard ingredient of slapstick comedy ..." {{cite book |last=Beaver |first=Frank Eugene |publisher=Peter Lang Publishing Inc. |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-8204-7298-0 |title=Dictionary of film terms: the aesthetic companion to film art |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jj7vAjkArz4C&pg=PA207#v=onepage&q&f=false |page=207}}</ref>
}}
==External links== * {{Tvtropes|RunningGag}}
[[Category:Running gags| ]] [[Category:In-jokes]] [[Category:Narrative techniques]]

revision.comment: add italics to first mention, removed tangential city template
revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | image_file = | painting_alignment = | image_size = | title = Saint Martin de Porres | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = Fr. Thomas McGlynn | year = 1963 | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = | museum = | coordinates = | owner = }}
'''''Saint Martin de Porres''''' is an artwork by [[United States|American]] artist and [[Catholic priest]] [[Thomas McGlynn|Father Thomas McGlynn]]. This sculpture, one of McGlynn's most well known works and is found in the collection of [[Providence College]] in [[Rhode Island]], [[Old Lady of Perpetual Help Church (Washington, D.C.)|Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], among others. It is a statue of [[Saint Martin de Porres]].<ref name="SOS1993">{{cite web | author=Smithsonian | year=1993 | title=St. Martin Fountain, (sculpture). | work=Save Outdoor Sculpture | publisher=Smithsonian | url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?&profile=all&source=~!siartinventories&uri=full=3100001~!319554~!0#focus | accessdate= 12 January 2010}}</ref><ref name="SOS1994">{{cite web | author=Smithsonian | year=1994 | title=Saint Martin de Porres, (sculpture). | work=Save Outdoor Sculpture | publisher=Smithsonian | url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?&profile=all&source=~!siartinventories&uri=full=3100001~!323793~!0#focus | accessdate= 12 January 2010}}</ref>
==Description==
The sculpture is a standing figure of Saint Martin de Porres wearing a [[cassock]] with a belt at the waist, he wears shoes. His head looks downwards, eyes somewhat closed, as if in deep thought or prayer. In his proper right hand he holds a [[Christian cross|cross]] to his chest and his proper left hand grips his leg with a broom under his arm.<ref name="SOS1994"/> Some of the works of this piece feature the Saint looking down at [[rat]]s that have gathered at his feet, often featuring 2-3 rats.<ref name="MartinHallSOS"/>
==Father Thomas McGlynn==
McGlynn was born May 23, 1906 to [[Frank McGlynn, Sr.|Frank McGlynn]] and Rose O'Beirne. On September 8, 1925 he received the habit of the [[Dominican Order]], taking the name Brother Matthew. At Dominic's Church in Washington, D.C., he was [[ordained]] a priest on May 20, 1932 by [[Michael Joseph Curley|Archbishop Michael Joseph Curley]]. Receiving his degree in sculpture in [[Rome, Italy]] in 1934 and returned to the United States to study at [[Cranbrook Educational Community]] studying under [[Carl Milles]]. After apostolic ministry and serving as faculty member at Providence College (1937–1938 and 1946), he went to [[Pietrasanta, Italy]] in 1956 commissioned to create a sculpture of [[Our Lady of Fatima]] and he remained in the country until his death on September 3, 1977.<ref name="MartinHallSOS">{{cite web | author=Smithsonian | year=1993 | title=Saint Martin de Porres, (sculpture). | work=Save Outdoor Sculpture | publisher=Smithsonian | url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?&profile=all&source=~!siartinventories&uri=full=3100001~!319555~!0#focus | accessdate= 12 January 2010}}</ref><ref name="McGlynn">{{cite web | author=Fr. Richard McAlister OP | year= | title=Dominican Priest and Sculptor Thomas McGlynn | work=Theology | publisher=Providence College | url=http://www.domcentral.org/library/McGlynn/default.htm | accessdate=12 January 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100501091551/http://www.domcentral.org/library/McGlynn/default.htm | archivedate=1 May 2010 | df= }}</ref>
==Inspiration and Creation==
Growing up, McGlynn was unaware of racial issues during his youth, using discriminatory terms as part of everyday life to describe [[African Americans]]. Upon entering the priesthood McGlynn states that "My meeting with Martin de Porres changed all that."<ref name="Homily">{{cite web | author=Fr. Pius Pietrzyk, O.P. | year=2010 | title=Fr. Thomas McGlynn and St. Martin de Porres | work=Friar Blog | publisher=The Dominican Province of Saint Joseph | url=http://www.op-stjoseph.org/blog/fr._thomas_mcglynn_and_st._martin_de_porres/ | accessdate= 12 January 2010}}</ref>
==Locations== Four versions of the sculpture exist, and the creation of this work is often credited with contributing to the [[canonization]] of the Saint in 1962.<ref name="2009McGlynn">{{cite web | author= | year=2009 | title=Selected Works of Thomas McGlynn | work=Thomas McGlynn | publisher=Providence College | url=http://www.domcentral.org/library/McGlynn/mcg09.htm | accessdate=12 January 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101229191514/http://www.domcentral.org/library/McGlynn/mcg09.htm | archivedate=29 December 2010 | df= }}</ref>
==Dominican House of Studies==
The original [[plaster]] version of the sculpture resided in the collection of the Dominican House of Studies in Washington, D.C. as of 1962.<ref name="2009McGlynn"/>
===Vatican===
The first, small version of the sculpture was created for use at the Vatican, completed in 1962.<ref name="2009McGlynn"/>
===Providence College===
Providence College has two copies of the sculpture, one in front of Martin Hall and a second at the McGlynn Sculpture Court, named after the sculptor. The Martin Hall sculpture, the fourth in the series, has no rats at the Saints feet, is made of [[bronze]] (H. 7 ft.) and was copyrighted in 1958 and dedicated on November 3, 1979.<ref name="MartinHallSOS"/> This version was originally designed for [[Saint Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx|Saint Raymond's Cemetery]] in the Bronx, New York City, and McGlynn decided to remove the rats believing that people would have an aversion to them being on a sculpture in a cemetery.<ref name="2009McGlynn"/> It was surveyed in 1993 by the [[Smithsonian Institution|Smithsonian's]] [[Save Outdoor Sculpture!]] program and was described as needing treatment.<ref name="MartinHallSOS"/>
The second sculpture, at McGlynn Sculpture Court, features several small rats at the Saints feet. This is an earlier version of the above piece, made also of bronze (H. 48 in. × W. 1 ft. 3 in.), created in 1962, cast in 1963 and dedicated on October 2, 1993. The sculpture stands in a small fountain. as part of the Sculpture Court which was built after the [[Dominican Province of St. Joseph]] donated their McGlynn Archives & Sculpture Collection to the College in 1980. This sculpture was described as well maintained by the Save Outdoor Sculpture! survey program.<ref name="SOS1993"/>
==Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church==
This version of the sculpture is made of [[wood]] (H. 12{{frac|1|2}} ft.) and does not feature the rats at his feet. It was dedicated on May 27, 1989 with the support of the St. Martin de Porres Guild and the founding pastor who wanted the church to be dedicated in the Saints honor. The funds for the work were provided by an endowment supplied by parishioner Mary A. Cooke, who hoped to have the statue erected inside the church school. The piece resides outside. The work was described as needing treatment in 1994 by the Save Outdoor Sculpture! survey program.<ref name="SOS1994"/>
===Roman Catholic Diocese of Raleigh===
On November 3, 2009, the parish of St. Joseph in [[Raleigh, North Carolina]] was presented a four-foot-tall version of the sculpture by Fr. Ambrose McAlister, Professor Emeritus of Art and Art History at Providence College, to celebrate the Feast of St. Martin de Porres.<ref name="Homily"/> This black marble casting was made from the 1930 version and was created in a Rhode Island-based foundry. It sits upon a table of white [[carrara marble]], which was crafted by parish member Bill Stephany. Fundraising for the work and installation was spearheaded by parish member Daisy Foster. Father McGlynn worked in Raleigh at St. Monica's from 1947 to 1954.<ref name="Raleigh">{{cite web | author=St. Martin de Porres | year= | title=St. Martin de Porres | work= | publisher=St. Joseph's Catholic Church | url=http://stjosephsraleigh.org/index.php?option=com_content&id=92 | accessdate= 12 January 2010}}</ref>
===St. Martin de Porres Shrine & Institute, Memphis, Tennessee===
The shrine chapel features a small version of the 1930 casting which shares the space with a [[relic]] of St. Martin as well as a stained-glass window and icons created by [[Pam Hassler]].<ref name="Shrine">{{cite web | author= | year=2010 | title=Shrine Artwork | work=The Shrine Chapel | publisher=St. Martin de Porres Shrine & Institute | url=http://www.stmartinshrine.org/shrinechapel.html | accessdate=12 January 2010 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100826074913/http://www.stmartinshrine.org/shrinechapel.html | archivedate=26 August 2010 | df= }}</ref>
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20101229190116/http://www.domcentral.org/library/McGlynn/mcg03.htm Learn more about Father McGlynn]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Saint Martin De Porres (Sculpture)}} [[Category:Providence College]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in Rhode Island]] [[Category:Culture of Providence, Rhode Island]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Sculptures of saints]] [[Category:Woodcarving]] [[Category:Catholic Church in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:African-American Roman Catholicism]] [[Category:1963 sculptures]] [[Category:Bronze sculptures in the United States]]

Sasaki is a global design firm specializing in [[architecture]], [[interior design]], [[Urban planning|planning]], [[urban design]], [[landscape architecture]], strategic planning, [[graphic design]], and [[civil engineering]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://segd.org/sasaki-associates|title=Sasaki Associates|last=Adona|first=Nadia|date=2015-12-08|website=segd.org|language=en|access-date=2018-01-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://gbdmagazine.com/2017/sasaki-resiliency/|title=Sasaki is Reimagining Resiliency to Build Stronger Communities - gb&d|date=2017-11-01|work=gb&d magazine|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en-US}}</ref>
== History == Sasaki was founded in 1953 by acclaimed landscape architect, [[Hideo Sasaki]] in [[Watertown, Massachusetts]], while he served as a professor and landscape architecture department chair at the [[Harvard Graduate School of Design]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/09/25/arts/hideo-sasaki-80-influential-landscape-architect-dies.html|title=Hideo Sasaki, 80, Influential Landscape Architect, Dies|last=Raver|first=Anne|date=2000-09-25|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> When Sasaki partnered with Peter Walker in 1957 the firm became Sasaki, Walker and Associates. In 1959, Walker opened up a new branch of the firm in San Francisco, and in 1964 the Watertown location was renamed Sasaki, Dawnson & DeMay.<ref>{{Cite web| title = Sasaki, Dawson & DeMay {{!}} The Cultural Landscape Foundation| accessdate = 2018-01-06| url = https://tclf.org/pioneer/sasaki-dawson-demay}}</ref>
Sasaki, Dawson and DeMay redesigned [[Copley Square]] in 1970.<ref>{{Cite news| title = A Unique Job: Expanding a Famed Architect's Legacy| work = The Boston Globe (Boston, MA)| accessdate = 2018-01-06| date = 2017-10-24| url = https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P4-1954151614.html}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal| last = Sasaki| first = Dawson| title = Copley Square| accessdate = 2018-01-06| date = 1858| url = http://dome.mit.edu/handle/1721.3/28767}}</ref> The firm's work includes Christopher Columbus Park (also called the Waterfront Park) and the plaza at the [[The First Church of Christ, Scientist|First Church of Christ]].<ref>{{Cite web| title = MUM'S THE WORD AT SMITH - The Boston Globe (Boston, MA) {{!}} HighBeam Research| accessdate = 2018-01-06| url = https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-8575742.html}}</ref>
Sasaki won an international design competition for the [[2008 Beijing Olympics]] Green. The design included over 1,700 acres of woods and wetlands. Alan Ward was the lead landscape architect.<ref>{{Cite news| issn = 0190-8286| last = DeFord| first = Susan| title = Looking Past Columbia For Its Center| accessdate = 2018-01-06| date = 2008-03-06| url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/03/05/AR2008030501762.html}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news| title = Master plan for Beijing Olympics| accessdate = 2018-01-06| date = 2003-03-27| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/front_page/2890191.stm}}</ref> Sasaki principal Dennis Pieprz also wanted the Olympic Green design to be useful in the long-term.<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = Monacelli Press| isbn = 978-1-58093-264-6| last = Goldberger| first = Paul| title = Building Up and Tearing Down: Reflections on the Age of Architecture| date = 2009}}</ref> The Olympic Forest Park is Beijing's largest public green space.<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = University of Texas Press| isbn = 978-0-292-77337-0| last = Steiner| first = Frederick| title = Design for a Vulnerable Planet| date = 2011-05-16}}</ref>
Led by Sasaki Principals Michael Grove, Mark Dawson, and Tao Zhang, the firm opened its [[Shanghai]] office in 2012 where it worked on influential projects including the [[798 Art Zone]], the master plan for [[Suzhou Creek]], and a vision plan for the [[Songzhuang art colony]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bdcnetwork.com/sasaki-opens-office-shanghai|title=Sasaki opens office in Shanghai|work=Building Design + Construction|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Architecture]] [[Category:Design]] [[Category:Landscape architecture]]

{{italic title}} [[File:Rembrandt, bue squartato, 1655, 01.JPG|thumb|''Slaughtered Ox'', 1655. Oil on panel. 95.5 x 68.8 cm. Louvre, Paris]]
'''''Slaughtered Ox''''', also known as '''''Flayed Ox''''', '''''Side of Beef''''', or '''''Carcass of Beef''''', is a 1655 oil on [[beech]] panel [[still life]] painting by [[Rembrandt]]. It has been in the collection of the [[Louvre]] in Paris since 1857. A similar painting is in [[Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum]], Glasgow, possibly by Rembrandt himself but probably by one of his pupils, perhaps [[Fabritius]].<ref>[https://artuk.org/discover/artworks/the-carcase-of-an-ox-85827 The Carcase of an Ox], ArtUK</ref> Other similar paintings by Rembrandt or more likely his circle are held by museums in Budapest and Philadelphia.
The work follows in a tradition of artworks showing butchery, for example [[Pieter Aertsen]]'s ''[[A Meat Stall with the Holy Family Giving Alms]]'' (1551) and [[Annibale Carracci]]'s ''[[Butcher's Shop]]'' (c. 1583), and perhaps more specifically [[Joachim Beuckelaer]]'s ''[[:File:Joachim Beuckelaer - Slaughtered Pig - WGA2122.jpg|Slaughtered Pig]]'' (1563). Rembrandt made a drawing of a similar scene c. 1635. Another pre-1655 painting of a slaughtered ox (the example in Edinburgh, now attributed to Rembrandt's circle but formerly to Rembrandt) was perhaps inspired by a lost earlier work by Rembrandt himself. In northern Europe, November was traditionally the time for slaughtering livestock, before winter made feed difficult to find.
The painting measures {{convert|95.5|x|68.8|cm}}, and is signed and dated "Rembrandt f. 1655". It shows the butchered carcass of a bull or an ox, hanging in a wooden building, possibly a stable or lean-to shed. The carcass is suspended by its two rear legs, which are tied by ropes to a wooden crossbeam. The animal has been decapitated and flayed of skin and hair, the chest cavity has been stretched open and the internal organs removed, revealing a mass of flesh, fat, connective tissue, joints, bones, and ribs. The carcass is carefully coloured, and given texture by [[impasto]]. In the background, a woman appears behind a half-open door, lifting the painting from [[still life]] into a [[genre painting]], a scene of everyday life. It is sometimes considered a [[vanitas]] or [[memento mori]]; some commentators make references to the killing of the fatted calf in the biblical story of the [[Prodigal Son]], others directly to the [[Crucifixion of Jesus]].
The painting was possibly owned by Christoffel Hirschvogel in 1661. It was viewed by [[Joshua Reynolds]] in the collection of [[Pieter Locquet]] in Amsterdam in 1781, and later owned by [[Louis Viardot]], who sold it to the [[Louvre]] in 1857 for 5,000 francs.
The work's muscular depiction inspired [[Honoré Daumier]], [[Eugène Delacroix]], a series of works by [[Chaim Soutine]], and [[Francis Bacon (artist)|Francis Bacon]]. Most particularly, Bacon's ''[[Figure with Meat]]'' depicts [[Pope Innocent X]], as painted by [[Velazquez]], accompanied by ghostly echoes of the carcass from Rembrandt's painting.
==Gallery==
<gallery> File:Rembrandt Harmensz. van Rijn 037.jpg|Similar painting in Glasgow, c. 1640, likely by a follower of Rembrandt File:Slaughtered ox Rembrandt.jpg|Similar painting in Budapest, 1639, likely by a follower of Rembrandt File:Rembrandt - Slaughtered Ox - Cat475.jpg|Similar painting in Philadelphia, 1640s, likely by a follower of Rembrandt File:Chaim Soutine - Carcass of Beef - 57.12 - Minneapolis Institute of Arts.jpg|Soutine, ''Carcass of Beef'', 1925 </gallery>
==References== <references/> * {{Cite book |author=van de Wetering, Ernst |title=A Corpus of Rembrandt Paintings |date=2015 |publisher=Springer |isbn=9789401791731 |pages=551–562}} * [http://cartelfr.louvre.fr/cartelfr/visite?srv=car_not_frame&idNotice=25565 ''Le Boeuf écorché''], Louvre * [http://www.rembrandtdatabase.org/Rembrandt/painting/232216/the-slaughtered-ox ''The slaughtered ox''], Rembrandt database * [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=oru8BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA555 ''A Corpus of Rembrandt Paintings V: The Small-Scale History Paintings''], edited by Ernst van de Wetering, p.551-562 * [http://jessieevans-dongrayart.com/essays/essay088.html Rembrandt van Rijn, 1606-1669, Carcass of Beef (Flayed Ox), 1655], Don Gray * [http://thecresset.org/2007/Deam_T2007.html Bloom: Rembrandt, Red Meat, and Remembering the Flesh], Lisa Deam, ''The Cresset'', Trinity 2007 (Vol LXX, No. 5, p 6-13) * [https://nielsbergervoet.wordpress.com/2011/07/29/rembrandt-and-the-slaughtered-ox/ Rembrandt and the ''Slaughtered Ox'']
{{Rembrandt|state=collapsed}}
[[Category:Paintings by Rembrandt]] [[Category:1665 paintings]] [[Category:Paintings of the Louvre by Dutch, Flemish and German artists]] [[Category:Still life paintings]] [[Category:Animal paintings]] [[Category:Animal killing]] [[Category:Cattle in art]]

revision.comment: Changed "paver stones" to read "stone setts, which is the correct term for the stones used for paving.
revision.text:
"Sous les pavés, la plage!" ('''Under the paving stones, there is a beach!'''), is a slogan from the [[May 1968 events in France|May 1968 protest movement in France]]. It was coined by student activist Bernard Cousin,<ref name=CousinObit>[https://www.lanouvellerepublique.fr/indre-et-loire/commune/montresor/mai-68-le-createur-de-sous-les-paves-la-plage-est-mort Mai 68 : le créateur de "Sous les pavés, la plage" est mort], at ''[[La Nouvelle République du Centre-Ouest]]''; published April 15, 2014; retrieved June 13, 2018</ref> in collaboration with [[public relations]] expert Bernard Fritsch.<ref name=CNEWS>[http://www.cnews.fr/france/2018-01-26/sous-les-paves-la-plage-il-est-interdit-dinterdire-les-slogans-phares-de-mai-68 «Sous les pavés la plage», «Il est interdit d’interdire»... les slogans phares de mai 68], at [[CNews]]; published January 26, 2018; retrieved June 13, 2018</reF>
The phrase became a symbol of the events and popular movement during the spring of 1968, when the revolutionary students began to build barricades in the streets of major cities by tearing up [[Pavement (architecture)|street pavement stone]]. As the first barricades were raised, the students recognized that the stone setts were placed on top of sand.
The statement encapsulated the movement's views on urbanization and modern society in both a literal and metaphorical form.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.histoire-en-citations.fr/citations/mai-68-sous-les-paves-la-plage Further reading]
[[Category:Slogans]]

{{Refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Korean words and phrases]]}} [[File:Homage rock 1885.jpeg|thumb|right|Korean artwork shows scholar paying homage to a special stone -- painting with calligraphy by Hô Ryôn, 1885]]
'''''Suseok''''' (수석), also called '''viewing stones''', is the [[Korea]]n term for small naturally occurring or shaped [[rock (geology)|rocks]] which are traditionally valued.<ref>[http://www.koreanviewingstones.com/ Suseok at KoreanViewingStones.com]; retrieved 2013-2-7.</ref> Such stones are similar to [[Chinese scholar's rocks]] and Japanese [[suiseki]].<ref name="brokaw73">Brokaw, Charles. (2011). [https://books.google.com/books?id=T51TNiU9460C&pg=PA73&dq= ''The Temple Mount Code,'' p. 73].</ref>
''Suseok'' can be any color. There are a wide variety of sizes. ''Suseok'' can weigh hundreds of pounds or less than one pound. The term also means stones which are placed in traditional Korean gardens.
==History== ''Suseok'' began as [[votive art]] over 3000 years ago, and began to be seen as worthy of scholars a thousand years ago. The art usually works on three scales: large installations of monumental shaped stones as ornamental gates; medium-sized shaped stones for landscape decoration within [[Korean gardens]]; and the smaller shaped stones for scholar's tables which is the most important.
Chinese scholar's rocks influenced the development of ''suseok'' in Korea.<ref name="brokaw73"/>
==Evaluation== Early on important sites within landscape were marked with shaped stones, much as those distance markers on post roads. Burial sites were as well given permanent marking by large scale tumulus or mounds, often surrounded by anthropomorphic shaped stones much akin to that of [[Inuit]] or [[First Nations]]' memory markers. The shamanistic belief of nature being alive, and large scaled elements of nature having souls, has led to the continued use of massive sculpted stone in natural forms throughout Korean traditional entranceways as the firstgrowth cedarwood for gates is now rare.
As Confucian scholarship ascended into the golden age of the [[Joseon Dynasty|Joseon]] dynasty, scholar rocks became an essential fixture of the writing tables of the [[yangban]] class of scholars, and a brilliant example of [[Confucian art]]. The repeated Japanese invasions of Korea, culminating with the 50 year occupation period from 1895 to 1945, saw great theft of Korean scholar stones as well as theft of larger pieces taken to Japan from [[Korean gardens]] or [[Seon garden]] and put into the [[Zen garden]] without reference to origins. Recreating a historical approach to Korean scholar stones is difficult, but it is being done.
Smaller ceramic versions of scholar's rocks have been seen cast in celadon, and used as brush-holders, and as well as water droppers for scholar's [[calligraphy]] - particularly in the shape of small mountains.
==Genres of Korean stone art==
* mountain view (horizontal and vertical) * shaped jade mountains * shaped rock crystal mountains * abstract shape * overhanging shapes * organic mineral shapes (calcites, pyrites) * stalactite and stalagmite stelae * shamanistic shape * single stone buddhas * multiple stone buddhas * astrological year figures (dragon, snake, monkey etc.) * tree and house shapes * fossilized fish * fossilized insects * enhanced coloured stones
==Standard reference work==
* Soosuk, #72 in a series of books on Korean culture, Daewonsa Publishing Co, Ltd (Korea, 1989), {{ISBN|89-369-0072-2}} (in Korean)
==See also== * [[Gongshi]] or Chinese scholar's rocks * [[Suiseki]] * [[Korean art]] * [[Korean sculpture]] * [[Korean culture]] * [[List of Korea-related topics]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.bucheon.go.kr/site/homepage/menu/viewMenu?menuid=002003002003 Bucheon Museum of Suseok at Bucheon.go.kr]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Stone art}} [[Category:Korean art]] [[Category:Korean sculpture]] [[Category:Rock art in Asia]]

The '''Symphony in C''' is a work by Russian expatriate composer [[Igor Stravinsky]].
The Symphony was written between 1938 and 1940 on a commission from American philanthropist Mrs. Robert Woods Bliss. It was a turbulent period of the composer's life, marked by illness and deaths in his immediate family. In 1937, Stravinsky was diagnosed with [[tuberculosis]], which had already forced his wife and two daughters to a sanatorium in Switzerland. Stravinsky's daughter Ludmilla and wife Catherine died of their illnesses in November 1938 and March 1939, followed by Stravinsky's own quarantine and the death of his mother Anna in June 1939.<ref>Phillip Huscher, [http://www.cso.org/main.taf?p=5,5,6,72 ''Program Notes: Symphony in C''] (Chicago: Chicago Symphony Orchestra, 2008); Igor Stravinsky, Liner notes for ''Stravinsky: Symphony in Three Movements; Symphony in C; Symphony of Psalms'' (CBS Records MK 42434, 1963/1988), pp. 4-5.</ref> He also suffered a [[cerebral thrombosis]] while conducting the symphony at a 1956 concert in Berlin, Germany.<ref>Igor Stravinsky, liner notes for ''Stravinsky: Symphony in Three Movements; Symphony in C; Symphony of Psalms'' (CBS Records MK 42434, 1963/1988), pp. 4–6.</ref>
Stravinsky was still mourning the deaths of his family members when World War II forced him to leave Europe.<ref>Phillip Huscher, [http://www.cso.org/main.taf?p=5,5,6,72 ''Program Notes'': Symphony in C''] (Chicago: Chicago Symphony Orchestra, 2008); Michael Oliver, ''Igor Stravinsky'' (London: Phaidon Press Limited, 1995), p. 138.</ref> He had written the symphony's first two movements in France and Switzerland. Stravinsky wrote the third movement in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]], and the fourth movement in [[Hollywood]], after his emigration to the United States.<ref>Igor Stravinsky, Liner notes for ''Stravinsky: Symphony in Three Movements; Symphony in C; Symphony of Psalms'' (CBS Records MK 42434, 1963/1988), pp. 4-5.</ref> The symphony was premiered by the [[Chicago Symphony Orchestra]] under Stravinsky on November 7, 1940.<ref>Philip Huscher, [http://www.cso.org/main.taf?p=5,5,6,72 ''Program Notes: Symphony in C''] (Chicago: Chicago Symphony Orchestra, 2008).</ref>
The Symphony in C is representative of Stravinsky's [[neoclassicism (music)|neoclassical]] period, which had been launched by his ballet ''[[Pulcinella (ballet)|Pulcinella]]'' (1919–20), the opera ''[[Mavra]]'' (1921–22), and Octet for winds (1922–23). The symphony has a traditional, four-movement structure and lasts approximately 30 minutes: #''[[Tempo|Moderato]] [[musical terminology|alla breve]]'' (about 9 minutes) #''[[Larghetto]] [[concertante]]'' (about 6 minutes) #''[[Allegretto]]'' (about 5 minutes) #''[[Largo (music)|Largo]]; Tempo [[musical terminology|giusto]], [[musical terminology|alla breve]]'' (about 7 minutes)
The Symphony in C is entirely abstract and seems a retreat into the 'pure music' styles of [[Bach]], [[Beethoven]], and [[Haydn]]. Stravinsky disclaimed any link between his personal experiences and the symphony's content.<ref>Jonathan Cross, ''[[Cambridge Companions to Music|The Cambridge Companion to Stravinsky]]'' (Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press, 2003), p. 115.</ref><ref name="Program Notes">Huscher [http://www.cso.org/main.taf?p=5,5,6,72 ''Program Notes].</ref>
Regarding its style, Stravinsky acknowledged a division of the symphony into halves.<ref>Stravinsky, liner notes, p. 5.</ref> The first two movements, composed in Europe, use more traditional rhythmic patterns and harmonizations. The last two movements use frequent modulations of rhythm and are much more chromatic.<ref name="Program Notes"/>
Stravinsky's misfortunes apart, the Symphony in C had been infrequently performed in the composer's lifetime; Stravinsky noted that for several years he was the only person conducting the work.<ref>Stravinsky, Liner notes. p. 5.</ref>
The work was choreographed by Martha Graham in the late 1980s. She named the result "Persephone" in ironic reference to another major work by Stravinsky. Although Graham choreographed all four movements, only the three-movement version was performed on stage.{{Clarify|date=October 2013}}<!--Stravinsky composed only a four-movement version. Did Graham make a version in which one movement was left out and, if so, which one? And where is all of this information documented?-->
== Notes == {{reflist}}

revision.comment: Reverted 2 edits by [[Special:Contributions/174.113.91.128|174.113.91.128]] ([[User talk:174.113.91.128|talk]]): Revert to spelling used in the source ("Brahman" here is Brāhmaṇa, not Brahman). ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox folk tale |Folk_Tale_Name = The Brahmin and the Mongoose |Image_Name = Herpestes edwardsii at Hyderaba.jpg |Image_Caption = [[Indian grey mongoose]] |Aarne-Thompson Grouping = 178A |AKA = |Mythology = |Country = India (origin) |Region = |Origin_Date = |Published_In = |Related = }}
'''''The Brahmin and the Mongoose''''' (or '''''The Brahmin's Wife and the Mongoose''''') is a folktale from [[India]], and "one of the world's most travelled tales".<ref name=b494>Blackburn, p. 494</ref> It describes the rash killing of a loyal animal, and thus warns against hasty action. The story underlies certain legends in the West, such as that of Llywelyn and his dog [[Gelert]] in Wales,<ref name=b494/> or that of [[Saint Guinefort]] in France.<ref name=greenwood/><ref name=b496/> It is classified as [[Aarne-Thompson]] type 178A.<ref>D. L. Ashliman, ''[http://www.pitt.edu/~dash/type0178a.html Llewellyn and His Dog Gellert and other folktales of Aarne-Thompson type 178A]''</ref>
==The story== [[File:8th century Panchatantra legends panels at Virupaksha Shaivism temple, Pattadakal Hindu monuments Karnataka 1.jpg|thumb|The woman and the mongoose ''Panchatantra'' fable is engraved in many historic Hindu temples such as at the 8th-century Virupaksha temple at [[Pattadakal]] (the middle panel).<ref>{{cite journal | last=Blackburn | first=Stuart | title=The Brahmin and the Mongoose: The Narrative Context of a Well-Travelled Tale | journal=Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies | publisher=Cambridge University Press | volume=59 | issue=03 | year=1996 | doi=10.1017/s0041977x00030615 | pages=494-506}}</ref>]] The original version from the [[Panchatantra]] in [[Sanskrit]] goes as follows (translation from {{Harvnb|Ryder|1925}}): {{quote| The Loyal Mongoose{{efn|The source uses the spelling "mungoose" throughout; the spelling has been here modernized to "mongoose" for consistency with the rest of the article.}}
There was once a Brahman named Godly [orig. ''Devasharma''] in a certain town. His wife mothered a single son and a mongoose. And as she loved little ones, she cared for the mongoose also like a son, giving him milk from her breast, and salves, and baths, and so on. But she did not trust him, for she thought: “A mongoose is a nasty kind of creature. He might hurt my boy.” [...]
One day she tucked her son in bed, took a waterjar, and said to her husband: “Now, Professor, I am going for water. You must protect the boy from the mongoose.” But when she was gone, the Brahman went off somewhere himself to beg food, leaving the house empty.
While he was gone, a black snake issued from his hole and, as fate would have it, crawled toward the baby’s cradle. But the mongoose, feeling him to be a natural enemy, and fearing for the life of his baby brother, fell upon the vicious serpent halfway, joined battle with him, tore him to bits, and tossed the pieces far and wide. Then, delighted with his own heroism, he ran, blood trickling from his mouth, to meet the mother; for he wished to show what he had done.
But when the mother saw him coming, saw his bloody mouth and his excitement, she feared that the villain must have eaten her baby boy, and without thinking twice, she angrily dropped the water-jar upon him, which killed him the moment that it struck. There she left him without a second thought, and hurried home, where she found the baby safe and sound, and near the cradle a great black snake, torn to bits. Then, overwhelmed with sorrow because she had thoughtlessly killed her benefactor, her son, she beat her head and breast.
At this moment the Brahman came home with a dish of rice gruel which he had got from someone in his begging tour, and saw his wife bitterly lamenting her son, the mongoose. “Greedy! Greedy!” she cried. “Because you did not do as I told you, you must now taste the bitterness of a son’s death, the fruit of the tree of your own wickedness. Yes, this is what happens to those blinded by greed....” }}
In Western variants of the story, other animals take the place of the mongoose, most often a dog. It is also found in other versions as a [[weasel]], cat (in Persia), bear, or lion, and the snake is sometimes replaced with a wolf (in Wales). The essence of the story, however, remains the same. Similarly, variants of the story sometimes have the man, instead of his wife, killing the loyal animal.<ref name=b498>Blackburn, p. 498</ref>
The story is sometimes placed within a frame story, where a saviour stands mistakenly accused and narrates this story, thereby preventing his own death.<ref name=b>Blackburn</ref>
==Origin and travel== The story was first studied in 1859 by [[Theodor Benfey]], the pioneer of comparative literature, when he compared the versions in India, the Middle East and Europe.<ref>Benfey, Theodor S. 1859. Pantschatantra.2 vols. Leipzig: F. W. Brockhaus; Benfey, Theodor S. 1862. 'Ueber die alte deutsche Uebersetzung des Kalilah und Dimnah', Orient und Occident, 1: 138-187.</ref>In 1884, W. A. Clouston showed how it had reached Wales.<ref>Clouston, W. A. 1884. [https://books.google.com/books?id=UnEAAAAAMAAJ The Book of Sindibad]. Glasgow: privately printed.</ref>
[[File:Gelert.jpg|thumb|250px|''[[Gelert]]'' by [[Charles Burton Barber]] (1845–1894)]] [[Murray B. Emeneau]] considers the migration of this story, through its steps from India to Wales, as "one of the best authenticated cases of such diffusions of folk-tales".<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.2307/985117| jstor = 985117 | pages = 503–513 | title = A Classical Indian Folk-Tale as a Reported Modern Event: the Brahman and the Mongoose | journal = Proceedings of the American Philosophical Society | volume = 83 | issue = 3 | publisher = American Philosophical Society | year = 1940| author1 = Emeneau | first1 = M. B.}}, p.507</ref> It is classified as [[Aarne-Thompson]] type 178A.<ref>D. L. Ashliman, ''[http://www.pitt.edu/~dash/type0178a.html Llewellyn and His Dog Gellert and other folktales of Aarne-Thompson type 178A]''</ref>
The story occurs in all versions of the [[Panchatantra]], as well as the later Sanskrit works [[Hitopadesha]]<ref name=hitopadesha> {{citation | year=2007 | title = "Friendly advice" by Nārāyaṇa and "King Vikrama's adventures" | author1=Nārāyaṇa | author2=Judit Törzsök (transl.) | publisher=NYU Press and [[Clay Sanskrit Library]] | isbn=978-0-8147-8305-4 | pages=513–515 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KdV9dMQci9sC&pg=PA513}} </ref> and the [[Kathasaritsagara]]. It also occurs in most of the languages of India (and South Asia) where it is extremely familiar. For instance, in the [[South India]]n state of [[Karnataka]], the story occurs as a proverb in inscriptions,<ref name=b496>Blackburn, p. 496</ref> as a sculpture in a temple,<ref> Mallikarjuna Temple at [[Pattadakal]], Karnataka, eighth century. See: * C. S. Patil (1995), ''Panchatantra in Karnataka sculptures'', Mysore: Directorate of Archaeology and Museums. </ref> in narratives of travelling storytellers and singers,<ref> Blackburn p.505 and 499. Found as ''The Sati of Sulochana'' in a collection of bard-stories: * Kyathanahalli Rāmaṇṇa (1972), ''Gondalingara Kathegalu''. Mysore: Institute for Kannada Studies. </ref> and in film.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A0MHirNAR9o Nodiddu sullagabahudu (video)] ("Things are not always what they seem"), from ''Rama Lakshmana'' (1980). Note that here, too, the story is framed within another story of an unjustly accused animal (a pet tiger).</ref> Similarly, the [[Tamil language|Tamil]] epic ''[[Silappatikaram]]'' recalls the story simply by its name.
Like the rest of the Panchatantra, in its westward migration it travelled from Sanskrit to Arabic (as ''Kalila wa Dimna''), Persian, [[Hebrew]], Greek, Latin, Old French, and eventually into all the major languages of Europe (as ''The Fables of Pilpay'' or ''Bidpai''), ranging from Russian to [[Goidelic languages|Gaelic]] to English. In its eastward migration, it appears in Chinese (ten versions, including in a redaction of the Vinaya Pitaka), and over a wide region from Mongolia to Malaysia. It is also the only story found in all recensions of the Panchatantra, all versions of the 'Book of Sindibad' (not [[Sindbad]]), and all versions of '[[Seven Wise Masters|The Seven Sages of Rome]]'.<ref name=b495>Blackburn, p. 495</ref>
It is also found in Mexico and the United States. Blackburn observes that the fable is not a dead tradition and is still current, as a Belgian newspaper reported it as an anecdote about a man who left his son and dog in a shopping trolley in his car.<ref name=b495/>
The motif also occurs, with a happy ending, in the Disney film ''[[Lady and the Tramp]]'' (1955).<ref name=greenwood/>
==Reception/influence== The story is often used in culture as an [[exemplum]] cautioning against hasty action. In addition, it also serves as shorthand for sin, regret and grief.<ref name=b/>
In Welsh it became the story of the nobleman Llywelyn who kills his loyal dog, [[Gelert]]. It was later interpreted as a legend about a true event, and small shrines to the dog exist in Wales (such as in the village of [[Beddgelert]], "Gelert's grave"). In France a similar metamorphosis took larger proportions, and the story became the cult of [[Saint Guinefort]] (a dog), which was popular until the 1930s.<ref name=greenwood>{{citation | author=Stephen Belcher | contribution=Panchatantra | title=The Greenwood Encyclopedia of Folktales and Fairy Tales | editor=Donald Haase | year=2008 | volume=2 | pages=723–725 | isbn=978-0-313-33441-2 | quote=…is a saint's legend behind a pilgrimage site in France.}}</ref><ref>Blackburn, p. 496. {{quote|When the dog replaced the mongoose, the tale was commonly interpreted as a legend (that is as a true event), and the loyal animal's undeserving death was commemorated by small shrines to the dog not only in Wales but also in north India […] On a larger scale, this tale inspired the cult of St. Guinefort in France…}}</ref>
Blackburn points out that although in the many literary versions it is the man who kills the mongoose, in most ''oral'' versions (and even the literary version quoted above), it is the woman who does so. Further, ''both'' literary and oral versions place the woman at the centre of the story, emphasizing her maternal feelings toward the animal, her mixture of love and fear, and her grief at its death. Thus he asserts that "the tale is a drama enacted between a mother and her son" and proposes some interpretations.<ref name=b501>Blackburn, p. 501</ref>
==See also== *[[Jock of the Bushveld]]
==Footnotes== {{notelist}}
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==References== * {{citation | author=Stuart Blackburn | year=1996 | title=The Brahmin and the Mongoose: The Narrative Context of a Well-Travelled Tale | journal=Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies | publisher=University of London | volume=59 | pages=494–507 | jstor=619805 | issue=3 | doi=10.1017/s0041977x00030615}} * {{citation | year=1925 | last=Ryder |first=Arthur W. | authorlink=Arthur W. Ryder | title=The Panchatantra | publisher=University of Chicago Press | isbn=81-7224-080-5}} * {{citation | year=1968 | title = Popular tales and fictions: their migrations and transformations, Volume 1 | editor1=William Alexander Clouston | editor2=Christine Goldberg | publisher=ABC-CLIO | isbn=978-1-57607-616-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Bjc-O6EaRR4C&pg=PT454 | pages=363–374}}
==External links== * [http://www.pitt.edu/~dash/type0178a.html Tales of AT 178A type] by Prof. D. L. Ashiman, with examples from other cultures

'''The Brick Theater''' is a 70-seat{{cite web|author=— Kaitlin Jessing-Butz |url=http://nymag.com/listings/attraction/Brick-Theater/ |title=The Brick Theater - Performing Arts Venues - New York Magazine |publisher=Nymag.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-17}}{{cite web|author=The Brick |url=http://newyork.timeout.com/arts-culture/theater/118678/the-brick |title=The Brick - Williamsburg - Theater - Time Out New York |publisher=Newyork.timeout.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-17}} state-of-the-art{{cite web|url=http://newyork.metromix.com/theater/theater/the-brick-theater-east-williamsburg/214977/content |title=The Brick Theater - East Williamsburg - New York , NY 11211 | Metromix New York |publisher=Newyork.metromix.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-17}} theater located at 579 Metropolitan Ave near the corner of Lorimer St in [[Williamsburg, Brooklyn]].{{cite web|last=Reznik |first=Eugene |url=http://www.thelmagazine.com/newyork/inspecting-the-brick-theaters-foundations/Content?oid=1666960 |title=Inspecting The Brick Theater's Foundations | Theater Reviews | The L Magazine - New York City's Local Event and Arts & Culture Guide |publisher=The L Magazine |date= |accessdate=2011-12-17}} Housed in a brick-walled{{cite web|url=http://www.visitbrooklyn.org/_webapp_1075687/The_Brick_Theater,_Inc |title=The Brick Theater, Inc |publisher=Visitbrooklyn.org |date= |accessdate=2011-12-17}} former auto-body shop/former yoga center on the first floor of a former industrial building, a weathered wooden garage door announces the entrance to what [[Gothamist]] hails as “one of the city’s most reliable sources for smart, funny, and surprising performance.”{{cite web |last=Del |first=John |url=http://gothamist.com/2008/03/13/michael_gardner.php |title=Michael Gardner, The Brick Theater |publisher=Gothamist |date=2008-03-13 |accessdate=2011-12-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120125111258/http://gothamist.com/2008/03/13/michael_gardner.php |archivedate=2012-01-25 |df= }} Founded in 2002 by co–Artistic Directors Michael Gardner and Robert Honeywell, The Brick has become known for its co-producing model and its “oddball,”{{cite web|author=Steven Mcelroy |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/10/theater/10webtheater.html?pagewanted=5 |title=Summer Stages - Theater Festivals - List |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=2009-05-07 |accessdate=2011-12-17}} “tartly-themed” summer festivals. The Brick has presented works from artists including [[Debate Society]], [[Eric Bland]]’s [[Old Kent Road Theater]], and [[Eddie Kim]], as well as staff-produced offerings from Gardner, Honeywell, [[Piper McKenzie]], [[Gemini CollisionWorks]], and [[The Fifth Wall]]. == Staff == Michael Gardner, co–Founder/Artistic Director{{cite web|url=http://www.offoffonline.com/article.php?ArticleID=42 |title=off-off-Broadway reviews, listings, and more |publisher=offoffonline |date=2009-06-04 |accessdate=2011-12-17}}
Robert Honeywell, co–Founder
Gyda Arber, Managing Director{{cite web|url=http://www.nytesmallpress.com/pp10/pp10int_arber.php |title=gyda arber interview |publisher=Nytesmallpress.com |date=2010-05-06 |accessdate=2011-12-17}}
Ian W Hill, Technical Director{{cite web|url=http://www.offoffonline.com/archives.php?id=1245 |title=off-off-Broadway reviews, listings, and more |publisher=offoffonline |date= |accessdate=2011-12-17}}
Berit Johnson, Technical Director
Roger Nasser, Box Office Manager == Summer Festivals == The Too Soon Festival (2010){{cite web|last=Kuntzman |first=Gersh |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/brooklyn/our_weekly_events_calendar_QPmhgMnJukRIhpvnj8TjFL |title=Our weekly events calendar! |publisher=NYPOST.com |date=2010-06-16 |accessdate=2011-12-17}}
The Antidepressant Festival (June 5–July 4, 2009)
The Film Festival: a Theater Festival (2008)
The Pretentious Festival (2007)
The $ellout Festival (2006)
The Moral Values Festival (2005)
The Hell Festival (2004) == Recurring Festivals == [[New York Clown Theater Festival|The New York Clown Theater Festival]]
Game Play{{cite web|last=Schiesel |first=Seth |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/16/theater/16video.html |title=Video Games - Theater and Video Games Meet at Brick’s Game Play |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=2010-07-15 |accessdate=2011-12-17}}
Tiny Theater Fest
The Baby Jesus One-Act Jubilee
Fight Fest{{cite web|url=http://newyork.timeout.com/arts-culture/upstaged-blog/108809/fight-fest-roundup-part-1 |title=Fight Fest Roundup: Part 1 - Time Out New York |publisher=Newyork.timeout.com |date=2009-12-11 |accessdate=2011-12-17}}{{cite web|url=http://newyork.timeout.com/arts-culture/upstaged-blog/108802/fight-fest-roundup-no-2 |title=Fight Fest roundup No. 2 - Time Out New York |publisher=Newyork.timeout.com |date=2009-12-18 |accessdate=2011-12-17}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/28/arts/28weekaheadweb.html |title=The Week Ahead - Nov. 28-Dec. 4 |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=2010-11-26 |accessdate=2011-12-17}}
The CollisionWorks{{cite web|last=Saltz |first=Rachel |url=http://theater.nytimes.com/2009/08/13/theater/reviews/13blood.html |title=Theater Review - 'George Bataille's Bathrobe' and 'Blood on the Cat’s Neck' - Fassbinder and Foreman on the Limits of Language - NYTimes.com |publisher=Theater.nytimes.com |date=2009-08-13 |accessdate=2011-12-17}} == Other Festivals == The [[Václav Havel|Havel]] Festival (2006){{cite web|author=[[Andy Propst]] |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2006-10-17/theater/foreign-intelligence/ |title=Foreign Intelligence - Page 1 - Theater - New York |publisher=Village Voice |date=2006-10-17 |accessdate=2011-12-17}} == Past and Current Shows == {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=50%}} ''Absence of Magic''

revision.text:
'''Touch-type Read and Spell''' is a computer program that uses the [[Orton-Gillingham|Orton-Gillingham Method]] to teach [[phonics]] and typing.<ref name="TTRS">{{cite web|url=http://www.readandspell.com|title=Touch-type Read and Spell|website=Touch-type Read and Spell|publisher=TTRS|accessdate=August 22, 2017}}</ref> It is a multi-sensory approach. Keyboarding lessons present words on the screen, play them aloud and provide visual cues of the intended hand movements. The program is multi-step and focuses on accuracy over speed. This makes it appropriate for students with [[dyslexia]] and other specific learning differences, [[Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder|ADHD]], [[Developmental coordination disorder|dyspraxia]], [[Functional illiteracy|adults who struggle with literacy skills]] and aphasic individuals [[Aphasia|recovering from a stroke]]. TTRS has been featured in the Guardian<ref name="Guardian">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2000/mar/28/furthereducation.theguardian5|title=Dyslexia Drive|last1=Midgley|first1=Simon|date=March 28, 2000|accessdate=August 22, 2017|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> and Forbes<ref name="Forbes">{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jennchoi/2017/08/01/cutting-edge-schools-show-how-education-is-everyones-business/2/#86442675f269|title=Cutting Edge Schools Show How Education is Everyone's Business|last1=Choi|first1=Jennifer|date=August 1, 2017|accessdate=August 22, 2017|publisher=Forbes}}</ref> and the course and its approach are commonly discussed in books<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Illustrated-Guide-Dyslexia-Amazing-People/dp/1785923307|title=The Illustrated Guide to Dyslexia and Its Amazing People|last=Power|first=Kate|last2=Forsyth|first2=Kathy Iwanczak|last3=Rogers|first3=Richard|date=2017-09-21|publisher=Jessica Kingsley Publishers|isbn=9781785923302|language=English}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=mVWnCNdUdMsC&pg=PA20&dq=%22touch-type+read+and+spell%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwip37ioirrWAhWKaVAKHVWRC_4Q6AEIZjAK#v=onepage&q=%22touch-type%20read%20and%20spell%22&f=false|title=Dyslexia: A Practical Guide for Teachers and Parents|last=Riddick|first=Barbara|last2=Wolfe|first2=Judith|last3=Lumsdon|first3=David|date=2012-10-12|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781136630286|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=IRuMAQAAQBAJ&pg=PT53&dq=%22touch-type+read+and+spell%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwip37ioirrWAhWKaVAKHVWRC_4Q6AEIWTAI#v=onepage&q=%22touch-type%20read%20and%20spell%22&f=false|title=Glue Ear: An Essential Guide for Teachers, Parents and Health Professionals|last=Peer|first=Lindsay|last2=Watson|date=2013-10-18|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781134024940|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=WUacBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA10&lpg=PA10&dq=%22touch-type+read+and+spell%22+the+dyslexic+advantage&source=bl&ots=R0XWaLMD2X&sig=VOh4G7QXmvkjCbPy2zaiuwPrDe4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjHsJmOh7rWAhUQLVAKHR3kAKY4ChDoAQg_MAQ#v=onepage&q=%22touch-type%20read%20and%20spell%22%20the%20dyslexic%20advantage&f=false|title=Brilliant Ideas for Using ICT in the Inclusive Classroom|last=McKeown|first=Sally|last2=McGlashon|first2=Angela|date=2014-12-04|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317611608|language=en}}</ref> concerning special needs classroom instruction and dyslexia.
